It appears I have been badly wrong.  These things happen. Still an outside chance, I suppose, that the GJedi will score it some other way, but they shouldn't.

1.  From OFAC on 3/24/16:   “The following changes have been made to OFAC's SDN List: 

ISLAMIC REVOLUTIONARY GUARD CORPS MISSILE COMMAND (a.k.a. IRGC MISSILE COMMAND), Tehran, Iran; Additional Sanctions Information - Subject to Secondary Sanctions [NPWMD] [IRGC] [IFSR]. -to- ISLAMIC REVOLUTIONARY GUARD CORPS AL-GHADIR MISSILE COMMAND (a.k.a. IRGC AIR FORCE AL-GHADIR MISSILE COMMAND; a.k.a. IRGC MISSILE COMMAND), Tehran, Iran; Additional Sanctions Information - Subject to Secondary Sanctions [NPWMD] [IRGC] [IFSR].”
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20160324.aspx 2.  From Dept. of Treasury Press Release on 3/24/16:  Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Al-Ghadir Missile Command

OFAC also updated its listing for the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Missile Command to include the names IRGC Al-Ghadir Missile Command and IRGC Air Force Al-Ghadir Missile Command.  The IRGC Missile Command was designated pursuant to E.O. 13382 on June 16, 2010.

The IRGC Al-Ghadir Missile Command is a specific element within the IRGC and appears to be the entity that has operational control of the ballistic missiles.  Officials from the IRGC Al-Ghadir Missile Command were involved in the October 10, 2015 medium-range ballistic missile (MRBM) launch.  The IRGC Al-Ghadir Missile Command officials were involved in other MRBM launches since as early as 2008. 

On March 8 and 9, 2016, the IRGC conducted two successive days of ballistic missile tests.  A senior missile commander in the IRGC indicated on March 9 that Iran’s missile program would not stop under any circumstances.
https://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl0395.aspx 3.  From 3/24/16 WSJ:  "The Obama administration on Thursday imposed sanctions against Iranian defense firms and units of Tehran’s elite military unit, the Revolutionary Guard, for their alleged role in supporting their country’s ballistic-missile launches." 
 http://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-sanctions-iranian-defense-firms-revolutionary-guard-units-for-missile-tests-1458837204 @clinton This one was truly a team effort.  I am sorry to see einsteinjs has left us.

I believe that they will not place sanctions on Iran because sanctions have already been placed. In addition, it takes quite a while in order for the US government to agree on anything, and in the midst of the election, America will be otherwise preoccupied.

The US will likely not agree to any new sanctions on Iran before said date because the republicans in congress are extremely against the Nuclear Plan, and President Obama will likely not risk a move that good upset democratic support right before an election. Also, Iran has mostly followed the restorations set by the sanction, so it's unlikely that new sanctions will be added unless something changes.

The nuclear deal suggests that new sanctions are unlikely. Iran has mostly followed the terms of the nuclear deal; President Obama wouldn’t want to go back on the agreement and betray US allies. The GOP cannot successfully pass sanctions unilaterally at this point. However, it is possible that Iran does something that justifies further sanctions.

My prediction: 20%
The US and UN have already imposed many sanctions, and with the US dealing with it’s own issues (Trump), I doubt much will be done to Iran. Also Iran has been laying low currently and doesn’t want to provoke the wrath of either the US or UN anytime soon.

I believe Connor has some good points about the inability of the United States Government to pass bills and sanctions. I also do not foresee Iran in the near future doing any nuclear tests or anything to provoke more attention about their nuclear program, however, Iran did a test in October of 2015 and sanctions were issued by January of 2016, so due to this quickness they have passed the sanctions in the past I give a higher probability of this occurring than Connor.

The US dropped some harsh sanctions for the ballistic missile test. Though Iran publicly denounced the sanctions, the economic and political implications of testing their luck again with more tests and nuclear productions would not be a smart move. With that said, it seems unlikely that the US will have to step into diplomacy sometime in the near future in order to control Iran's nuclear production process.

Moving up by 1% my well above consensus 90 to 91%. 
Rationale:

BOTH the D's & R s need to be seen as moving in the direction of the AIPAC to generate its critical support. Neither party needs or wants to been as a "chicken" politically speaking to the new Iranian flexibility provided by the recent US/Iranian deal; especially considering the present angst/terrorism atmosphere.  1. Whether the Senate Democrats will take violations of the Iran deal seriously is the fundamental question posed by JP.  Clear implication being failure to take identifiable/concrete action leaves the D party open to accusations it remains unsupportive of Israeli concerns over Iranian actions.    http://m.jpost.com/Opinion/Will-Senate-Democrats-take-violations-of-the-Iran-deal-seriously-448855#article=6017RjM0Q0VGOUMzOUU4OTBEQTNDNjM5M0E2REEwRDAyM0Y=
Clearly, w/o any significant/concrete action on the Senate floor by the Democrats, DT gains a doubled edged sword to say: 1) look they are only toeing the Obama administration line  &, 2) the GOP has an opportunity for greater leverage w/ the Jewish lobby vote by coming out in favor of attempting to "set sanctions" should the D's fail to come up w/ substantive action proposals.The attached http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-u-s-senate-takes-on-iran-1458605304 WSJ argues a Senate sanctions bill is a good start to countering the Iranian missile program http://www.thetower.org/3127-wsj-editorial-senate-sanctions-bills-are-good-start-to-countering-iranian-missile-program/ 2. Both Clinton & Trump essentially argued they were "friends" of Israel yet " waffled "   on whether they would support any specific Congressional concrete action over Iran. NB: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/22/us/politics/hillary-clinton-and-donald-trump-vow-to-protect-israel-but-differ-on-means.html
Up 10%. Token US response even though not a good idea.

With momentum gaining after the Spring recess, the Senate and House will most likely move forward with sanctions against Iran - given the last two missile launches.  With Republican control of the Congress, it is unlikely that such a bill would be formulated or co-sponsored if there was an unlikely possibility of the bill being passed.   Doing so before the November elections, is is highly probable that such an outcome can occur.   On the UN front, with Russia and China holding veto power in the Security Council, passing a resolution on new sanctions against Iran is most unlikely.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-u-s-senate-takes-on-iran-1458605304 there seems to be a fairly bipartisan consensus to get something passed

Sanctions are not so long ago removed and restore them in the near future will show no consistency in decisions. Launching missiles can accelerate this process, whether Iran is ready to accept new sanctions - under question. Conflicts with neighbors also will accelerate the adoption of new sanctions, I start with a lower probability. The Iranian leadership is now more loyal than in the past.

Downgrading to 30% Republican Senators have introduced a bill to impose more sanctions on Iran on the basis of terrorism and humans rights violations. Democrats and the Obama administration aren't likely to pass the bill.  http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/03/17/456331/GOP-senators-sanctions-Iran Maintaining a 30% chance due to the erratic nature of the Iranian regime (particularly Khamenei and the IRG) and the fact that they still have steps in the nuclear agreement that they need to follow through on.

Following @cmeinel https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/178467 I was at 15% for the most of February, went up to 55 in anticipation of a new test, and 95 after the missiles were actually launched. I still think there's a good chance of the US imposing further sanctions in the next 7 months of an election year, but the difference in wording between the original "shall not..." and the current "called upon not to..." provides sufficient reason to lower the probability. The UN is ruled out, but the US can always take independent action (it doesn't have to be specifically missile or nuclear related). My original rationale from 10 February - "I don't think the UN will, since it would need the support of Russia and China to do so. The US Congress might, and in certain circumstances Obama may not use his veto. The section of Iran's government that is responsible for developing missiles and supporting regimes in Iraq and Syria could do something that provokes a new round of sanctions, but the chances appear to be low at this time." There are also potential sanctions for cyber-hacking.

That darn fine print in the U.N. resolution against Iran missile tests! It appears that those recent  these tests are legal! Combine this with the Obama Administration giving a pass to those  Bowman Avenue Dam hackers, by an amazing coincidence ran their attack from a location next door to Iran's military intelligence headquarters. What now do we have? Not much of a chance of new sanctions. Grrr. Dateline 3-16-16 Before the July 2015 nuclear pact, Iran was expressly prohibited by U.N. resolutions from launching ballistic missiles capable of developing nuclear weapons. U.N. Security Council resolution 1929 states that the 15-nation body “decides that Iran shall not undertake any activity related to ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.” In U.N. legal parlance, invoking the word “decides” places an unambiguous legal obligation on all states to comply.  Last July’s U.N. Security Council resolution 2231 — which endorsed the nuclear pact — replaced the prohibition with more permissive language: “Iran is called upon not to undertake any activity related to ballistic missiles designed to be capable of delivering nuclear weapons.” There’s just one problem: The updated measures are neither legally binding nor as restrictive than the measures in place at the time of the nuclear pact. In essence, resolution 2231 provides Iran with a loophole big enough to develop medium- and long-range missiles without the risk of running afoul of Security Council dictates. It also complicates efforts to define what kinds of missiles are capable of carrying a nuclear warhead.
 http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/03/16/washington-made-it-easy-for-iran-to-fire-its-ballistic-missiles/

Iran to U.S.: it's just a coincidence that the Bowman Avenue Dam hackers ran their attack from a location next door to our military intelligence headquarters. Honest to Betsy! U.S. to Iran: Yeah, OK, we believe you. If those hackers, surely just script kiddiesl, decide to show up in court, we're sure, yeah, um, er, that indictment will show 'em. Sheesh, how bad does it have to get before the U.S. imposes new sanctions on Iran. Dateline 3-16-16 [U.S. Sen. Charles Schumer] confirms expected indictment of Iranian hackers for N.Y. dam breach....  Cylance Vice President of Strategy Jon Miller told SCMagazine.com that the Iranian hackers attacked critical infrastructure targets in the U.S. and internationally. The attackers, who Miller termed “unsophisticated attackers,” did not successfully evade attribution. The group appeared to be located about 1.5 miles away from the Iran's military intelligence location, he added. The hackers are likely the same group behind Operation Cleaver, an offensive attack by Iranian hackers that breached the U.S. Navy Marine Corps intranet, said Miller. The Iranian hacking group SOBH Cyber Jihad claimed responsibility for the Bowman Avenue Dam incident, according to Flashpoint Intelligence. “Oftentimes their claims are opportunistic,” a source at the intelligence firm told SCMagazine.com. “It could be this group. Or it could be that they are blowing smoke in our face.” http://www.scmagazine.com/update-schumer-confirms-expected-indictment-of-iranian-hackers-for-ny-dam-breach/article/483351/
Obama and Iran have a lot riding on the Iran nuclear deal. They are both very motivated not to cause sanctions to occur.
US is pushing for sanctions in the UN Security council. whether or not Russia blocks them, the US may have its own response. Seems more likely than not based on the probabilities.

U.N. sanctions highly unlikely. Dateline 3-15-16 ...Russian Ambassador Vitaly Churkin, who said that in the view of veto-wielding Russia, Iran's ballistic missile tests did not violate resolution 2231. The resolution "calls upon" Iran to refrain from certain ballistic missile activity. Western nations see that as a clear ban, though council diplomats say China and other council members agree with Russia's and Iran's view that such work is not banned. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-australia-iran-trade-idUSKCN0WH066

no chance of UN sanctions http://news.yahoo.com/russia-opposes-sanctions-iran-ballistic-missile-test-143231950.html but very possible US sanctions http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=2492572&language=en (edit: see also http://www.foreign.senate.gov/press/chair/release/corker-iran-testing-will-of-us-and-international-community-after-second-straight-day-of-ballistic-missile-launches)

http://www.thetower.org/2090-schumer-iranian-cyber-attack-on-new-york-dam-was-shot-across-the-bow/ new angle - sanctions could be imposed in response to a cyber attack and/or missile testing. cc @clinton @einsteinjs

"Resolution 2231, which was brought into effect in January, used the term “calls upon” Iran to avoid activity for ballistic missiles. While the U.S. and Israel claim that Iran is banned from testing ballistic missiles, Russia and Iran claim that the term “calls upon” is not legally binding." (@cdob63, as you've been saying, there it is, the 'fuzziness of the language') (http://www.ibtimes.com/irans-foreign-minister-denies-missiles-violate-un-resolution-says-they-are-self-2336539) From Amb. Powers: "Power said that the missile test merits a response from the Security Council, but that Russia's contention that the launches did not violate Resolution 2231 all but rule out any council action."  (http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/03/15/iran-foreign-minister-denies-missile-test-breached-un-rules.html) I'm going back down to high 50s. Procedurally, getting unilateral or UN sanctions imposed against Iran for the most recent missile test is going to resemble molasses oozing uphill, but its possible in 216 days. I also maintain that something/anything else worthy of sanctions could happen before 18 October. 2016

The US will push for Security Council action in the face of a sure Russian veto.  This means the US is not deeply committed to Security Council action.  There may yet be US sanctions, but not until after the Security Council dance is well and truly ended. Since the US is clearly in no hurry, this could be a while.  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-missiles-un-idUSKCN0WG1NG
The U.S. congress may twist arms to impose new sanctions, but the current President will not sign the legislation unless something catastrophic happens and he is left with no choice.
Adjusting up a bit based on recent provocative actions by Iran. Still a low-prob event due to the desire of most parties for recent deals to be perceived as successful.
U.S. sanctions ruled out by Russia. Dateline 3-14-16 Russia says no new U.N. sanctions on Iran over missile tests http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-iran-missiles-un-idUKKCN0WG1NE

Iran has just gone out of sanctions and is still in need of cash enhanced by oil trade and contracts performance until then,  leaving them with little interest in pulling back from steps made towards international integration.  Plus,  the fact that civil society showed ever more eagerness to support reformists demonstrated recently both at the General Assembly and the  Assembly of Experts, means that openness has been gaining momentum.

Comments:
No love lost between Obama and Netanyahu, but this is an election year; GOP and Clinton will use this as a yelling point. RU and PRC as permanent members of the UNSC will most likely block any UN action. If EU, led by FR, imposes sanctions for continued tests, USA may be pressured into following. 
Adjusting up.

While Congress has been calling for new sanctions based on the recent ballistic missile tests, Obama and Kerry have expended too much political capital to not try and make the nuclear deal work. Also, there will be some significant chunks of time where congress will not be in session that will reduce the likelihood of passing a bill on this issue (i.e. summer recess). While the state department has indicated it is exploring unilateral action, Obama nor Kerry have indicated a desire to impose new sanctions by executive order.  It is doubtful that the UN security council will drum up new sanctions on this issue either. China and Russia won't have it based on their eagerness to cultivate their economic relationship with Iran.  Still, erratic behavior by Khamenei and the IRGC could force Obama's hand to act swiftly with a fresh round of sanctions. Also, any new developments on its failure to comply with the nuclear deal will need to be closely watched.  Setting to 35% for the time being.
Popular opinion in Iran is moving towards reform but not aggressively that it could cause political unrest. President Obama is politically motivated to make the nuclear deal work.

US has scheduled a UN Security Council meetin on Monday.  Security Council Resolution 2231 reportedly intended to prevent Iran from launching nuclear capable missiles.  While not a violation of the nuclear agreement, it may lead to new sanctions. -- NYTimes 3/12 a6

Got a little carried away yesterday with my jump up to 100. 
Posting a history of Iran sanctions: http://www.rferl.mobi/a/explainer-iran-sanctions/26915788.html

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-missiles-usa-idUSKCN0WD2IC UN sanctions are not at all likely over the missiles issue--see the couple of grafs about Resolution 2231 toward the bottom of the story.  You don’t refer an issue to the Security Council for discussion and expect fast action anyway. Unilateral US sanctions are not unprecedented; there is a long dance to be done first, but perhaps not a six-month one.  Internal US political considerations will play a part in this as in all matters, but it’s not immediately clear in which direction they will nudge the current administration, what with one thing and another.  Moving up some anyway.

Members of the U.S. Congress are pushing for new sanctions in response to Iran’s recent ballistic missile tests. Iran denies that the tests violated its international nuclear agreement or U.N. resolutions. Yesterday, a U.N. spokesperson said Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is urging Iran to show restraint and stop its missile testing, saying, “In the current political atmosphere in the Middle East region, and so soon after the positive news of the lifting of sanctions against Iran, the secretary-general calls on the government of the Islamic Republic of Iran to act with moderation, caution and the good sense not to increase tensions through any hasty actions.”
http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/03/11/u-s-to-consider-new-sanctions-after-iranian-missile-tests/
* * * 
It seems so unlikely that Congress will take a decision during this time frame.

New sanctions are being discussed in Congress (http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/03/11/u-s-to-consider-new-sanctions-after-iranian-missile-tests/). After the last set of missile tests and took about 3 months for new sanctions be imposed. By that measure, new sanctions could be in place by October. However, it seems unlikely that Congress would take such a big step before the election.

Iran test-fired two ballistic missiles yesterday: http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/03/10/iran-missile-tests-violate-no-deals/81578348/. From what I gather (C-SPAN, news websites, pundits, etc.), these tests do not violate the nuclear treaty signed last year, but do violate a UN resolution. I believe the decision makers in Iran calculated that they need to keep the nuclear treaty alive but can risk additional sanctions by conducting their military business negotiated as concessions in the nuclear deal (no inspection of military sites, no restriction on non-nuclear tests, etc.). So they did it! This news greatly increases the odds of fresh sanctions from an irate UN Security Council and US Congress, which, ironically, will probably play into the Iranian hardliners' plans to maintain their stronghold on the parliament.

Dateline 3-9-16 Iran carried out a series of ballistic missile tests from underground silos on Tuesday in exercises dubbed "The Power of Velayat," as the U.S. promised diplomatic retaliation. Iran claims the missiles in Tuesday's exercise have ranges of up to 2,000 kilometers, which if true would put Israel within striking distance. U.S. diplomats say they're cooking up an "appropriate response" to the tests. And FP’s John Hudson reports that some members of Congress are pushing for more sanctions, and more action by Washington. The missile exercises don't violate the recently-signed Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action nuclear agreement with Iran, but the U.S. says they do violate preexisting United Nations Security Council resolutions prohibiting ballistic missile tests. Situation Report: Foreign Policy [fp@foreignpolicy.com]

Iran Test-Fires 2 More Ballistic Missiles Despite Threat Of New Sanctions From US.  Iran test fired two new ballistic missiles early today despite threats of new sanctions from the US just the day before when, according to Reuters, it claimed to have "test-fired several missiles from underground silos" that hit a target 434 miles away. The missiles tested today were fired from the northern part of the country, hitting a location in the south as far as 870 miles. Sounds like Iran is on a roll.  The US Department of State said that it was investigating the claims and that if true, it would bring it to the UN Security Council. That doesn't sound to me like a strong enough deterrent and this type of incidents are likely to continue and get more serious.  http://www.ibtimes.com/iran-test-fires-2-more-ballistic-missiles-despite-threat-new-sanctions-us-2333013 Increasing forecast from 20 to 60.

This doesn't sound like a nation that is becoming more moderate. OK, the U.N. isn't enthusiastic about protecting Israel. But I expect the Security Council members would not like for Iran to make good on these threats. Israel has nuclear weapons and the means to deliver them and the fallout -- literally -- would affect a good part of the planet. Dateline 3-9-16 Iranian agencies said the missiles tested on Wednesday were stamped with the words "Israel should be wiped from the pages of history" in Hebrew. http://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2016/03/09/world/middleeast/09reuters-iran-missiles.html

COMMENT:  Iran is pushing the envelope.  Sooner or later there will be push-back.  I think there's time for that to happen while this question is open.

"As the cases described above demonstrate, Iran has relied on illicit procurement networks in strategic diversion points, such as Turkey, to advance its nuclear and missile programs.  Even with the nuclear agreement in place, Iran may continue to procure missile and arms related items illicitly because it does not accept an ongoing U.N. ban on such trade.  Therefore countries should exercise extra vigilance in exporting such items to known transshipment hubs, like Turkey.  If these countries served as a hub for illicit trade in the past – when stringent international sanctions were in place – there is every chance that their role will expand in the future, as trade flows to Iran increase. " 
http://www.iranwatch.org/our-publications/nuclear-iran-weekly/ceo-us-metallurgical-company-charged-illicit-export-metallic-powder-iran

Iran is not currently under a Security Council resolution forbidding This Sort of Thing, but they are under one that strongly suggests they oughtn't to test any missiles that are "designed" to carry a nuclear warhead. Given that almost any missile powerful enough to leave the ground could carry some sort of nuclear weapon, Iran must decide how to describe what they're doing.  They are saying it's just to improve the missile's accuracy so it can carry lovely conventional weapons in a more socially acceptable manner. The US has said it may refer this to the UN Security Council, a sure sign that the US isn't planning to do anything unilateral (and knows the Security Council won't impose sanctions for this). Nobody wants to impose new sanctions while the ink is still wet on the nukes deal, and the Iranians know this.   In short, this is choreography, and all the dancers will be careful not to bash into one another during the difficult bits.

My 9% chance of yes really means "no."  I expect Iran will continue to make it difficult to verify what their nuclear intentions.  Since they need money, and since our President has "worked" this deal, my forecast is that the status quo will continue and Iran will try to stockpile as much money for oil as they can while economic sanctions are lifted. There goal is to become a nuclear power and they will say and do whatever it takes to get them to that goal.

Iran has currently several reasons that support avoiding further sanctions, including:
- Getting the benefits from the nuclear deal including: ability to sell oil, unfreezing of foreign assets and access to foreign financial markets
- Being consistent with the last elections which confirmed the electorate preference for the reformists
- Adherence so far with the requirements of the nuclear deal On the other side Iran could get new sanctions by:
- Directly intervening in conflicts such as Sirya or Yemen
- Violating the arms embargo Under current circumstances, considering a relative "stability" of the situation in Sirya, the costs of getting new sanctions outweigh the benefits. I thus believe Iran will most likely avoid to incur in new sanctions (15% probability)
The current agreement is relatively new and the world will wait to see how the agreement is holding before making new moves.

The Iran deal will remain in sharp focus is US political circles heading into the US presidential elections. While the US and Iran's administrations will do everything in their power to support the deal, parliaments of both countries are strongly opposed to the deal and have high vested interests to thwart it. It is important to note that new sanctions imposed by the US or the UN do not necessarily nullify the nuclear deal. This was evident in the Jan 2016 sanctions that took effect even as Iran released some high-profile prisoners. I understand none of this is prohibited by the Iran Nuclear Agreement, in fact, the agreement paved the way some of these negotiations to continue.  In contrast, a UN resolution passed on July 20, just days after the nuclear agreement was signed, forbid Iran from making conventional arms sales for the next five years.
In January, just days after lifting sanctions based on compliance with the nuclear agreement, the US imposed new sanctions on 11 Iranian entities and individuals that it saw linked to a ballistic missile launch that Iran conducted in October.   Some of the weapons that Iran is looking to purchase are exempt from the UN Resolution 2231.  
What the ban forbids is “battle tanks, armored combat vehicles, large-caliber artillery systems, combat aircraft, attack helicopters, [and] warships…” from being purchased by Iran without prior approval from the UN.

Once the Russian back Syrians stabilize the front around Aleppo I'd not be surprised to see Hezbollah troops back on the Israeli border for a Spring offensive. They have a bunch of new toys and tactics to tryout. It could be a rough Summer over there.

From a US domestic perspective, Obama and his administration have staked a lot on the Iran deal. Approving additional sanctions will be seen as implicitly conceding that the Iran deal was no good. The new missiles do increase the chance of it happening, but it may take a change of administration to change things. As it is, I also think it unlikely that the UN will approve sanctions if the US does not agree.

per the lads (@scholarandcat, @clinton, @einsteinjs), Iran shows no signs of backing off from its ballistic missile testing program, and further tests (very likely to occur) are also likely to incur further sanctions. The people in control of the missile testing program are not necessarily the same as those in control of JCPOA implementation, and anyway Rouhani seems to be on board with their agenda wrt missile testing (in public at least). I think the consensus on this one is way out and would like to see a detailed explanation from someone on the other side as to why it isn't.

Raising from 3% to 68%. Looks like I whiffed big time on my first take of this IFP (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/129767). Major h/t to @scholarandcat & @clinton for this thread --> https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/131207 Here's one piece of what I contributed to that thread that's motivated me to be far more bullish on this IFP than I initially thought to be.
~~ Feb 10: "Iran to upgrade missiles, get Russian defense system: minister" --> http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-arms-russia-idUSKCN0VJ0MN Iran will unveil an upgrade of its Emad ballistic missiles this year, the defense minister was quoted as saying, advancing a program that has drawn criticism from the United Nations and sanctions from the United States. The Islamic Republic would also start taking delivery of an advanced Russian S-300 surface-to-air missile defense system in the next two months, Hossein Dehghan added - a system that was blocked before a landmark nuclear deal with world powers. Tehran agreed the deal on curbing its nuclear work in July last year and international sanctions were lifted in January. But tensions with Washington have remained high as Tehran continues to develop its military capabilities. Iran first tested the Emad missile in October. With improved accuracy over its existing arsenal, Iran says the new missile will be an important part of its conventional deterrent. But the United States says the Emad is capable of carrying a nuclear warhead and the test therefore violated a U.N. resolution. Washington imposed fresh sanctions last month against Iranian individuals and businesses linked to the missile program. "We will unveil the next generation of Emad with improved precision in the next (Iranian) year (starting from March 20)," Dehghan was quoted as saying by the Fars news agency late on Tuesday. "The Emad missile is not a violation of the nuclear deal or any U.N. resolution since we will never use a nuclear warhead (on it). It's an allegation," he said, adding that mass production would begin in the near future. Iran is also due to start taking delivery of the S-300 missiles system from Russia in the next two months, Dehghan said, and the order would be completed by the end of the year. ~~ Feb 9: "Iran soon to showcase controversial missile" --> http://en.trend.az/iran/politics/2492073.html In particular, several Western sources claimed that Tehran violated the UN Security Council’s resolution 2231 by test-firing the Emad, suggesting it is capable of carrying a nuclear warhead. The UNSC resolution 2231, adopted July 20, 2015, endorses the nuclear deal between Tehran and the world powers and calls upon Iran not to undertake any activity related to ballistic missiles that can deliver nuclear weapons, as well as launching ballistic missiles, such as Emad. ~~~ Jan 31: "Iran To Go On ‘Offensive’ In Response To US Missile Sanctions" --> http://dailycaller.com/2016/01/31/iran-to-go-on-offensive-in-response-to-us-missile-sanctions/ The commander of Iran’s ballistic missile program has responded to new U.S. sanctions against the program by stating that the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) response will be “offensive.” 
[...] 
Iran’s missile program is controlled by the IRGC, Iran’s vanguard military wing, which takes orders directly from Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Khameini. Iran’s president Rouhani has essentially no control over the organization, which has been actively undermining Rouhani since his election. The group is separate from Iran’s traditional military, and is considered the “ideological custodian charged with defending the Islamic Republic against internal and external threats,” according to a backgrounder by the Council on Foreign Relations. The IRGC has its own air force, navy and army and is also in control of the paramilitary Quds force, which engages in covert operations abroad. It is also responsible for coordinating with Iran’s proxy groups abroad, such as Lebanese terrorist group Hezbollah. ~~ COMMENT: So, Iran will definitely have another missile launch, it seems like it's a question of when that is. Based on the first link, it looks like it'll be sometime after March 20th, which is still 7 months from Oct 18th. The last link was really helpful for me to understand that it's not necessarily the "rational" actors within Iran who are responsible for the missile launches.

Why ruin a perfectly agreeable and possibly congenial anniversary date when you can just target "individuals and entities" per @Moomtastic
Better question would be how many G20 heads of state will be there on such auspicious date.

It's important to note that the new sanctions are being levied against "individuals and entities" associated with Iran, but not on the country itself. As it stands, there aren't a lot more sanctions the US can impose on Iran, unilatterally, and the UN hasn't added any sanctions to Iran since 2010. The most devastating sanctions in recent history were the 2012 EU sanctions against Iranian petro-chemicals. (http://www.cfr.org/iran/international-sanctions-iran/p20258). If the US really were upset over Iranian cheating, they'd likely go to Brussels (and also avoid a Russian or Chinese veto in the UN). One of the difficulties with a sanction regime like those faced by North Korea or Iran is that the lengths to which those countries have to go to circumvent sanctions often means it can take the treasury department a long time to figure out who or what precisely needs to be blacklisted in order to turn up the pressure, one notices that the sanctions against those responsible for Iran receiving ballistic missile parts took around 3 months from the missile's test. Stronger sanctions at this point typically mean stronger enforcement or stricter rules to scare business off from doing business with anyone who might be associated with Iran, which is unlikely to be well-received by those looking to get in on Iran's opening economy. All of that said, there's always the possibility of hardliners on either side deciding that antagonism is better for business. 4-5% rounded down to 4 to get away from the consesus because I'm a rebel.
There is a very strong desire within the US administration to be seen playing nicely with Iran, with any disputes carefully choreographed on both sides.  Needs watching, though.

Iran is going through many changes at the moment, with the old guard hanging onto past policies, and the new guard attempting to influence and shift policy. Recently some Iranians who were barred from political office had their status changed to allow political campaigning, though it remains to be seen who may emerge from this action. Iran likely does not fully trust some recent actions and agreements, and wiser individuals often hedge their bets. The bigger change evolving is the positive impact to the Iranian economy, and this may lessen the possibility of "inappropriate" actions in 2016. The more economically engaged that Iran becomes, the less the risk, or need for new sanctions. The wild card in this is actions in Syria, which may result in contentious activity.

To me, the missile issue was the only area of overt contention, and sanctions were passed already. I am still leaving a little room here, just in case Iran does something particularly outrageous.

I see this IFP as very similar to one of the other IFPs that was just published about removing Iran from the state sponsors of terrorism list (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/129699), so I'll include a passage of my reasoning from there: But let's build on that. Remember when it was announced that Cuba was going to be removed from the list? That was in April of last year, but Cuba wasn't *officially* removed from the list for another 45 days. Why? There was 45-day review period where Congress could consider blocking the action with a join resolution. So, even if we allow for the fact that the Obama administration might do something unexpected (like this) [as a quick aside -- let's remember that Obama ordered a review of Cuba in December, so 4 months prior them being taken off the list], but right let's forget both of those things for a moment... this act of removing Iran from this list would still have to get through the GOP Congress -- in an election year! It is at this point that I feel obliged to refer you back to the YouTube video I first referenced at the beginning.  ~~~ COMMENT: Alright -- so we're not having to worry about a 45-day waiting period, but some of the other bits from there apply -- if Congress passes sanctions against Iran, do we really think that Obama would sign them into law? And as for the State Department (or the WH) imposing sanctions unilaterally, there would have to be something going TERRIBLY wrong in Iran for that to happen given the Obama Administration's (likely) desire to continue to sell this plan as a major accomplishment (and it really is, honestly). Having to impose sanctions at the conclusion of Obama's term might sour the legacy, no? Don't get me wrong, I absolutely think that if *they* think it's necessary, they will, but as I said, it's going to have be something that's pretty bad.  Also, there's the "UN" to consider in this, but I don't think the UN would be imposing sanctions against Iran if the US isn't.

This is unlikely. The nuclear deal wasn't just about uranium and centrifuges, it was a first step toward welcoming Iran back into the good graces of the global community. The fight against ISIS has changed the equation in the middle east, and the West has no choice to but to grudgingly accept Iran as an ally against a common enemy. As other official sanctions are lifted, countries will have more economic tools to put pressure on Iran and the UN won't be as necessary. Iran is happily counting money and they no longer need to do things like missile tests to get international attention. I don't think they want to risk any of the gains they've made recently.

The US Congress has lots of ideas on this that aren't likely to make it to an Obama signing. The Executive could impose his own, as he did recently for the missile test. Iran could test another missile.  The UN isn't likely to do anything short of a nuclear deal infraction, which seems pretty secure until at least Oct. Iran would have to do something pretty egregious to set-off PRC and Russia on the UNSC.  For me it comes down to another missile test or an unknown unknown.
Would go lower (don't expect reasonable things to pass the US Congress and be signed by President Obama) but there is a possibility that something narrow (cyber-related) might be imposed.
